meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! Wuthering Waves has got everyone talking – and by everyone, I mean the critics. Let's dive into this free-to-play gatcha game and see if it lives up to its promising reviews.

First off, kudos to Movies Games and Tech for acknowledging that Wuthering Waves is trying to get us to spend our time (and maybe even some cash) in their world. Transparency, much appreciated! And honestly, who doesn't love a good gatcha game? It's like playing Pokémon, but with more anime-styled characters.

Now, let's talk about the positives. GamingBolt thinks Wuthering Waves is solid out of the gate, and I agree – that combat is pretty snappy, and exploration can be super fun. But what really gets my goat (or should I say, hippo?) is when critics praise games for being "solid" without giving me any concrete reasons why. Tell me, dear readers, what's so solid about Wuthering Waves? Is it the 3D graphics? The satisfying combat? Or maybe it's just because it's not a complete disaster? Help me out here.

INVEN thinks Wuthering Waves excels with its fast action and pretty graphics, but then mentions that the storyline is weak. Hmm, sounds like they're trying to be all things to all people – give me some decent storytelling, folks! But hey, at least they acknowledge the flaws instead of just glossing over them.

Now, let's get to the not-so-great stuff. But Why Tho? thinks Wuthering Waves has a lot of problems (no surprises there), but at least it has some strong story moments. That's more like it – give me some emotional payoff, game developers!

GLHF on Sports Illustrated (try saying that three times fast) says Wuthering Waves is trying too hard to be like Genshin Impact and ends up feeling outdated. Ouch, burn! But they do give it props for having fun combat and a fresh movement mechanic. That's some constructive criticism right there.

Finally, Jeuxvideo.com says Wuthering Waves takes everything that made Genshin Impact successful (yawn) but tries to stand out with its advanced action gameplay and elegant art direction. However, they're kinda harsh on the French translation – sorry, France! Maybe try translating it into Hippo-ish instead?

All in all, Wuthering Waves has got some great elements going for it – just don't expect me to be jumping for joy (get it? Like a hippo?). It's a solid game, but not without its flaws. I'd recommend giving it a shot if you're looking for some action-packed open-world fun, but don't say I didn't warn you about those story issues. Hippo Penny, out!
